title: Prophetic Covenant Critique
objective: Recognize prophetic enforcement of covenant obligations

required_passages.text: I hate, I despise your feast days, and I will not smell in your solemn assemblies. Though ye offer me burnt offerings and your meat offerings, I will not accept them: neither will I regard the peace offerings of your fat beasts. Take thou away from me the noise of thy songs; for I will not hear the melody of thy viols. But let judgment run down as waters, and righteousness as a mighty stream.

segments.audio_script: This is lesson twenty. You are studying prophetic covenant critique. Lesson nineteen examined the temple and centralization.

I hate, I despise your feast days, and I will not smell in your solemn assemblies. Though ye offer me burnt offerings and your meat offerings, I will not accept them: neither will I regard the peace offerings of your fat beasts. Take thou away from me the noise of thy songs; for I will not hear the melody of thy viols. But let judgment run down as waters, and righteousness as a mighty stream.
Prophets arise to call Israel to covenant faithfulness. They critique ritual without justice. Prophetic literature is covenant enforcement. God is not satisfied with mere external observance.
Prophetic covenant lawsuit follows ancient trial form. God prosecutes Israel for covenant breach. Prophets specify violations. Judgment is predicted consequence. Repentance is offered alternative.
Key themes: prophets enforce covenant stipulations. Justice and righteousness are covenant obligations. External ritual without inner transformation is rejected. Repentance is persistent call.
What does the prophet say God requires instead of sacrifice?
This completes lesson twenty. You studied prophetic covenant critique. Next lesson begins Unit Five on exile and restoration.

vocabulary.definition: Divinely inspired speeches calling Israel to covenant faithfulness and warning of judgment
Prophetic prosecution of Israel for covenant breach following ancient legal procedure

study_notes: Prophetic literature demonstrates that covenant relationship requires both internal faithfulness and external justice. Ritual without righteousness is rejected.
